description: From Middle English depthe, from Old English *dƒ´ep√æ (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *diupi√æ≈ç (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), equivalent to deep +‚Äé -th. Cognate with Scots deepth (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Saterland Frisian Dj√ºpte (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), West Frisian djipte (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Dutch diepte (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Low German Deepde (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Danish dybde (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Icelandic d√Ωpt (‚Äúdepth‚Äù), Gothic êå≥êåπêåøêçÄêåπêå∏êå∞ (diupi√æa, ‚Äúdepth‚Äù).

entries.meaning: the vertical distance below a surface; the degree to which something is deep
examples: Measure the depth of the water in this part of the bay.

entries.meaning: the distance between the front and the back, as the depth of a drawer or closet
(figuratively) the intensity, complexity, strength, seriousness or importance of an emotion, situation, etc.
examples: The depth of her misery was apparent to everyone.
The depth of the crisis had been exaggerated.
We were impressed by the depth of her knowledge.

entries.meaning: (computing, colors) the total palette of available colors
(art, photography) the property of appearing three-dimensional
examples: The depth of field in this picture is amazing.

entries.meaning: (literary, usually in the plural) the deepest part (usually of a body of water)
examples: The burning ship finally sunk into the depths.

entries.meaning: (literary, usually in the plural) a very remote part.
examples: Into the depths of the jungle...
In the depths of the night,
in the depth of the crisis

entries.meaning: (logic) the number of simple elements which an abstract conception or notion includes; the comprehension or content
(horology) a pair of toothed wheels which work together
(aeronautics) the perpendicular distance from the chord to the farthest point of an arched surface
(statistics) the lower of the two ranks of a value in an ordered set of values
